DOC.HEAD: Pope Heralds Christ's Birth in Midnight Mass
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II heralded the birth of Jesus in a Christmas Eve midnight Mass in St. Peter's Basilica beamed to millions on television. ``I bring you good news of a great joy,'' John Paul said, opening his homily quoting from Luke. ``To you is born this day a Savior.'' Pilgrims and tourists packed St. Peter's, the largest church in Christendom, and the pope greeted ``all people, on every continent'' who listened on radio or watched on television. The Vatican said it expected the Mass to be televised to about 50 countries, including John Paul's native Poland, the Soviet Union, Hungary and _ for the first time _ East Germany. Earlier, in an interview broadcast by Italy's state-run RAI-TV, the pope praised the wave of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe, lamenting only that the bloodshed in Romania at Christmas time was a ``sad and painful'' exception. ``But it's a step in the same process. (It is) the past and the future of our continent.'' He called the European events ``extraordinary'' and said Eastern Europeans who suffered as a result of World War II were ``finally emerging as winners.'' John Paul began his Christmas activities blessing a 100-foot-high tree from Austria and a nativity scene with life-size figures in the center of St. Peter's Square at noon on Sunday. He said Christmas eve was a ``wait full of hope as we prepare to welcome Christ who comes to us as savior of the world.'' In brief remarks, he said that while wars, rivalries, arrogance and selfishness were obstacles to peace, ``the optimism of hope is not naive.'' Later, in his homily, the pope said, ``On this Bethlehem night all of us are called _ once again _ to rejoice in the work of creation.'' ``The church, which on this night proclaims `a great joy,' knows that this joy comes completely from God. It is the gift of his love,'' the pope said. On Christmas, the pope will celebrate another Mass in St. Peter's and then deliver his traditional message ``Urbi et Orbi'' _ Latin for ``to the city (of Rome) and the world.''
